--should introduce

And he will explain what
those buzzwords mean when it's his turn to talk. But Justin is just an example
of the variety of speakers.

We're going to have
companies like Hermes. Who else are we going
to have for Christine? Do you remember? Folks spanning
investing founders

of startups, government. So-- Right. So one of the interesting
things about being a student

is unless you've been in
the Department of Defense, this is like alphabet soup.

What are these
organizations, who are, how they're related
to each other, it's hard to remember that
the Department of Defense

is the largest company
probably in the world or certainly in
the Western world. There are three million
people both civilians

and enlisted, all
working together. And that org chart could take
up probably this entire room.

So what I thought I'd do is just
give you the first 10 minutes. And teaching team jump in when
I get this wrong about what

does that look like. And how did we start the DOD? If you think about it, when
the United States got created,

we simply had something
called the War Department. That's all it was. It was war. Every other country
had a War Department.

A War Department was, gee, we
had land forces called the Army. And we had people in
these wooden ships

with sails called the Navy. And a couple of years
later, we probably said, instead of
shooting each other,

we should probably talk
to each other as well and have diplomats
in an organization. And we set up something
called the State Department.

And then, by the way, the
Navy realized that, oh,

when we have ships, we
ought to have soldiers on that ships besides cannon. We ought to have specialized
soldiers who could board

other ships or maybe land on-- fund the ships. And we set up the Marines. And eventually, about 40 years
later, the Navy said, yeah,

but those Marines, since
they're on our ships, should be part of the Navy. And so ever since then,
the US Marine Corps

is actually a service
as part of the Navy. That stayed the same for
another 100 or some odd years.

But in 1926, some
folks in the Army realized, hey, those airplanes
we used in World War I,

they were kind of useful
for not only spotting artillery and other things. We actually used them in
combat, and we used them

on early bombing
missions, et cetera. Gee, the Army should set
up a separate Air Corps.

But it should work for the Army. And so in 1926, the US military
looked like War Department,

which was then just the Army. And the Army had an Air Force. And the Navy had the Marine
Corps besides all the ships.

But in 1941, we renamed the
Air Corps into the Air Force.

And in 1947, after
World War II ended, we decided to get our
little act together.

Instead of the War
Department, we said, well, that's a little too aggressive. Why don't we call it
the Defense Department?

I hope some of you are laughing,
going, it's the same thing. But we did a little
branding exercise.

And we did some reorganization. We basically said, OK,
we'll have the Army.

But this time, the Air Force
is going to be its own service. So we spun out the Air Force
from underneath the Army

to become a service, a
separate organization. And we set up two
other organizations.

We set up an Office of
the Secretary of Defense. And we created a civilian in
charge of all our military

in the United States called
the Secretary of Defense. Does that make sense? And then we also set up
a way to badly coordinate

all those services, something
called the Joint Chiefs of Staff, which is
just a fancy term for,

gee, we'll have representatives
from the Army, Navy, Marines, Air Force, et cetera, all
sitting around the table arguing

with each other. But at least they're talking
to each other in a building. Makes sense so far? We're up to 1947.

And at the same
time, we realized that advice to the President
of the United States

was typically ad hoc, meaning we
had advisors to the president.

But there really
wasn't anything formal. And so part of this
National Security Act, we set up something called
the National Security Council.

And it had representatives
from Defense and State and Army, Air Force, Navy.

And it basically was designed
to give the president advice about national
security policies,

whether it was war or peace, or
something else, and diplomacy.

You're with me so far? In 1986, after wars in
Vietnam and particularly wars

in Grenada, we realized that
having separate services, Army,

Navy, Marines, Air Force no
longer worked in the 20th

century or didn't work well. Why? Because they were no longer
fighting separate activities.

When I was in
Vietnam, it was truly the Navy bombed this
part of Vietnam, and the Air Force bombed
this part of Vietnam.

And they sometimes
talked to each other. But mostly like for air traffic
control, there was no strategy.

They used different
equipment, different radios, different whatever. And it only got worse. And so we realized that we
needed to do something radical.

And the radical part
today is that the services you might know, from
those you're not

in the military, Army,
Navy, Marines, Air Force, do not fight the wars, big idea.

We created a new construct,
think of it as a matrix organization, called
combatant commands.

And the combatant commands are
the ones that fight the wars. The services,
they're still around.

They recruit the people. They train them. They buy the weapon systems. But they provide soldiers,
sailors, and equipment

to the combatant
commands that actually are geographically organized.

So we have services
training and equipping, combatant commands fighting. And we beefed up the
Joint Chiefs of Staff

to now they're
responsible in theory for planning and coordinating. And so the combatant
commands are--

most of them are geographic
AFRICOM, CENTCOM, EUCOM,

INDOPACOM, which you might hear
a lot about, it's the South China Sea, NORTHCOM, SOUTHCOM.

And then we have functional
ones that take care of cyber, CYBERCOM, special
forces like SEALs

and whatever, SOCOM,
STRATCOM and-- It's more to Special Forces
than the SEALs just-- So keep going,
the Rangers, the--

My husband will disagree. Yeah. Ferguson's got some close ties. This is-- Great. But every service has their
own special operating forces.

Let me be clear. But they all fall
under this bucket. What used to be the
Strategic Air Command

and whatever now are
all the nuclear forces are under STRATCOM. And transportation, all the
C-17's and C-5's, et cetera,

C-130s all fall under TRANSCOM. And then 2019, we stood up
one for space called SPACECOM.

These are the organizations
that actually Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, all man and
staff these organizations.

But their weapons systems come
from the services themselves. Again, here's just
a geographic map.

Again, as I said, we
stood up the Space Force as its own organization
as part of the Air Force.

So now, like the Navy that has
ships, and planes, and sailors,

it also has combat
troops and Marines. The Air Force now has air force
that does stuff, Guess where,

in the air, and a space force
that does something in orbit. And so the Air Force now
has two organizations,

much like the Navy. Remember that National
Security Council that started out
pretty simply in 1947?

It got a little
more complicated. There are what's called
statutory attendees, those that,

quote, "officially" on paper,
are responsible for advising the president. And then think of
these as the people

from here on up who
actually do the work. Eric, is that a job
of fair conversation? But truly, when you hear the
word NSC or National Security

Council, it's not
part of the military. But they're getting
advice from all pieces of the military, from
White House, from CIA,

et cetera, from Commerce. DOD today, and this is my
introduction to Justin,

kind of looks like this. There's the
Secretary of Defense. There's the Navy, Army,
Air Force, Joint Chiefs.

And then you also have
the combatant commands. You also have
activities that support

the Department of Defense in

Security Agency, the National

Reconnaissance Office? All these are-- National Geospatial
Agency, all these

are basically defense
agencies that support the DOD. But they're part of the DOD. Just as an aside,
anybody know how many

intelligence agencies that are
in the Department of Defense? Anybody know?

ATF 18 is in the IC. I don't know how many-- There you go. 17 are in the DOD, There's 17
separate intelligence functions

inside the DOD, each
with thousands of people. What's the one that's not in
the Department of Defense? CIA.

CIA, reports directly
to President. By the way, as an aside,
CIA has special authorities.

So the DOD operates, for any
of you interested in details, and there's something
called Title X. CIA has

special authorities called
Title 50, which makes life particularly interesting
when they get what's called a finding from the
president that says go

do X. The DOD can't
do X. But the CIA is actually chartered to do X.

Let me introduce

And that's not like

But our adversaries or

Do you have some slides? Do you want to do a Q&A? Or what would be best for you? I want to do a Q&A on you first.

Well, that org
chart is a big one. The world has gotten smaller.

I think we've all experienced

So from a experience

in the military and IC.

And in case you were intimidated

five years for me,

has gotten smaller

And so what I'd tell you
is, number one, be patient. And then number two,
be patiently impatient.

In general, we're doing a
marathon by way of sprint.

This long, kind of large,
arduous system wants to work.

In some ways, it's a perpetual

At times, there is less than
20% less than 5% of the people who are potentially like
doing iceberg type work.

But when you find them,
everything can change. And so there are a
number of externalities

that catalyze activity. And one, as of recently is,
and I have a slide on this

I'll show you, is
the Davidson Window. And so the Chief of Naval
Operations, the CNO, the four

Franchetti, the first female CNO

in Navy history, just put
out what junior officers

have told me is the most urgent
NAV plan in at least the last 20

years. And so she points
directly to the 2027,

hey, let's make sure that we're
ready to defend tonight and take

urgent action across the board
from an integration perspective across the Navy. The commandant of
the Marine Corps,

so Department of Navy,
Navy and Marine Corps, is working every day to get
his troops to fight smarter.

So two big changes
afoot are, one, you have the Navy that is
looking at hybrid options,

that is looking to disrupt
itself at different speeds. And then you have a Marine
Corps that did something,

and you can Google this later,
but Force Design 2030 that said, hey, we want to
shake ourselves up.

We are more like Netflix
than blockbuster now.

And we are looking
at how we really change the way that we operate. And their mantra right
now is fight smarter.

And so I want to
talk about, I guess, my time in Silicon Valley,
as well as any of the things

that you'd like covered for
how we bring new entrants in, how we think about this world

in-q-tel that gets 25 external dollars for every
dollar that they spend in here.

And so not everyone in the DOD
gets the new way of business.

Not everyone in any organization

what that can look like, and what it already

But before we do that-- Yes. --tell us what the

So I was just with some
esteemed folks over the weekend.

I know you guys have

Obviously, that position has

if it's not already.

And so we know and we
recognize that there needs to be more technical
people and mindset

in the government. And so I am essentially the
second person to hold this role.

I think it's been around
for four years total. And it's seated under the
Chief Information Officer.

So day job, military. Night job, I teach
at Georgetown.

I teach tech classes that don't

time, CTO is under CIO.

This is the type of business
that is like a digital org, like pure play digital org.

And then other times, the
CTO is even with the CIO or in a different place. In this particular case,

based on that
information shaping. And so I would tell you
that more of the world

is connected to the information

information shaping,

what we call information

information warfare, and cyber

were thought of as very

in military affairs below,

like direct kinetic
is very real and very palpable and noticeable.

The idea of shaping how the
defense region, the defense

organization and the

information, it's felt real.

That has been a little

is to work with the
combatant commands, to work with the
service as a whole,

and to listen and
help shape what we're doing with industry and

combatant commands. The actual kind of day-to-day
of what that looks like,

well, you're nowhere

communicating, internally

and externally, the importance
of information in our decision making, and the way that we
optimize, secure, and execute

as a Department of Navy. The other hat is tech
director for PEO Digital.

That's a mouthful, so
Program Executive Office. Who's heard of

OK. So oftentimes, if

they say the Holy
Grail is selling into a program of record. Turns out there are a lot
of programs of record.

And all of the programs of
record, for the most part, roll under something
like a program management

office, which roll up to a PEO. So don't glaze over on me. We're almost done
with this part.

But acquisition, the idea of
spending $250 billion or so

per year on acquiring things
all happens, for the most part,

through these PEOs. My PEO digital hat
is eight portfolios

of cyber infrastructure,
end user devices, transport,

the workplace services. All of the things that you
think of whenever you think

of information technology,
and then probably a little bit beyond that are

And so the kind of advantage
of having the CTO hat that does strategy and
policy and connecting

that does forecasting,

and execution of
shaping way forward, and execution of
piloting way forward

for these eight portfolios. This is one of those cases in
the government where I have an amazing team on both sides.

And we can shake and bake. And we can go really quickly
to learn from each other,

to connect dots, and
to make things happen. And so to give you a
quick example there is

we recently finished a project
that was slated for 36 months.
It hit the fan. And we finished it in 93 days. We can talk about that one.

There was another project where

about 17 months.

And so point is, when

your US government and
Department of Defense can make big things happen.
